description: In Yemen,the Governor of the Hadhramaut province imposed a curfew in Al-Sheher, Al-Days, Al-Sharqiyah, Al-Raida and Qsaye'r from eight in the morning on April 10 until six in the morning on Saturday, April 11 after the official announcement of the first case of the new Corona virus in Al-Sheher city.

description: On May 5, the Southern Transitional Council (STC) announced a partial curfew from 10 p.m. to 12 p.m. in Aden and the two governorates under its control (Lahj and Al-Dhale) for three weeks, starting May 6. All international organizations operating in STC-controlled governorates are excluded from the curfew, as are health care workers and employees of gas stations and hotels, on a limited basis.

description:
On March 28, the Yemeni Ministry of Civil Service and Insurance  announced that the work suspension to 80 per cent of the state’s employees, including the elderly and those suffering from chronic diseases, except for the health, security and services sectors would last until June 14th.

 UPDATE: The policy was initially supposed to be revised after 2 weeks, but it wasn't. This new update sets an end date to the policy.

description: To help protect prisons from an outbreak of the virus, the Yemeni local authorities in Shabwa governorate released 43 prisoners on March 28 after a review of their individual cases by a committee formed by Shabwa governor Mohammed Saleh Bin Adyo in coordination with the governorate’s chief prosecutor.
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: On March 29, the prosecutor’s office in the province of Al-Mahra in Yemen released 49 prisoners who had served two thirds of their sentences to ease the overcrowding of prisons. The authorities in Al-Mahra say they have paid 17 million Yemeni riyals, nearly $31 thousand in bonds to secure the release of prisoners in those cases requiring a financial surety that the defendants will reappear if summoned.
